content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata xml:lang="en"> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>The Wilderness Society</origin> <pubdate>2011</pubdate> <title>Potential Evapotranspiration Estimates (mm) for for Alaska, CRU TS3.0. The Wilderness Society, 2011.</title> <geoform>raster digital data</geoform> <onlink>http://www.snap.uaf.edu/downloads/alaska-climate-datasets</onlink> <onlink>http://arcticlcc.org/products/spatial-data/show/potential-evapotranspiration-cru-historical-dataset</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract> Potential Evapotranspiration (PET):  These data represent decadal mean totals of potential evapotranspiration estimates (mm). The file name specifies the decade the raster represents. For example, a file named pet_mean_mm_decadal_CRU_Historical_annual_1930-1939.tif represents the decade spanning 1930-1939. The data were generated by using the Hamon equation and output from a statistically downscaled version of the Hadley Centre's CRU TS3.0 observational dataset. Data are at 2km x 2km resolution, and all data are stored in geotiffs. Calculations were performed using R 2.12.1 and 2.12.2 for Mac OS Leopard, and data were formatted into geotiffs using the raster and rgdal packages.  Users are reminded that the PET estimates include the inherent uncertainty of model projections. In addition, the methods used to derive PET from temperature require a number of assumptions, which future conditions may or may not meet. In particular, these methods as implemented assume that cloudcover and relative humidity remain constant. This may or may not be true.  Hamon Equation: These data were derived by applying the Hamon equation as outlined in Lu et al. (2005) to monthly average temperature downscaled by SNAP. </abstract> <purpose>The Wilderness Society derived potential evapotranspiration from temperature projections to better understand how potential future warming might influence the surface water budget.</purpose> <supplinf>Historical CRU data provided by SNAP.  The data files downloaded from SNAP represents a single month within a given year for downscaled 'Climate Research Unit, University of East Anglia' (CRU) historical data with years 1901-2006 coming from the CRU high-resolution 0.5x0.5 degree gridded dataset 'CRU TS 3.0' (http://www.cru.uea.ac.uk/cru/data/hrg/) and years 2006-2009 from the CRU 5x5 degree gridded dataset (http://www.cru.uea.ac.uk/cru/data/hrg/). These files were created by taking the values of the downloaded CRU data and scaling them down to a 2-km resolution using the Parameter-elevation Regressions on Independent Slopes Model\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds (PRISM) 1961-1990 monthly climatologies for Alaska (http://www.prism.oregonstate.edu/), which take into account elevation, slope, and aspect. Please note that these maps represent climate estimations only. While SNAP has based their work on the best data and methods available, uncertainty is inherent in modeling.</supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>1910</begdate> <enddate>1999</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>ground condition</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>Unknown</update> </status> <spdom> <bounding> <westbc>-180.000000</westbc> <eastbc>180.000000</eastbc> <northbc>74.855485</northbc> <southbc>46.118994</southbc> </bounding> </spdom> <keywords> <theme> <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Category</themekt> <themekey>climatologyMeteorlogyAtmosphere</themekey> </theme> <place> <placekt>User</placekt> <placekey>Alaska</placekey> </place> </keywords> <accconst>None.</accconst> <useconst>It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data to evaluate data set limitations, restrictions or intended use.  The Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning, The Wilderness Society and the Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.</useconst> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>The Wilderness Society</cntorg> <cntper>Wendy Loya</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype> <address>705 Christensen Dr.</address> <city>Anchorage</city> <state>Alaska</state> <postal>99501</postal> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>907-272-9453</cntvoice> <cntfax>907-272-1670</cntfax> <cntemail>wendy_loya@tws.org</cntemail> <cntinst> Contact_Instructions:  Please direct questions about SNAP or the downscaled temperature projections to:  University of Alaska c/o Nancy Fresco SNAP Network Coordinator P.O. Box 757200 Fairbanks, Alaska 99775-7200 USA 907-474-2405 (voice) 907-474-6184 (FAX) nlfresco@alaska.edu Hours_of_Service: 8:30am - 4:00pm </cntinst> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> <datacred>The Wilderness Society and Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning</datacred> <secinfo> <secsys>FIPS Pub 199</secsys> <secclass>No Confidentiality</secclass> <sechandl>Standard Technical Controls</sechandl> </secinfo> <crossref> <citeinfo> <origin>Scenarios Network for Alaska Planning</origin> <pubdate>2008</pubdate> <title>Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning, 2008 - Air Temperature CRU.</title> <geoform>raster digital data</geoform> <onlink>http://www.snap.uaf.edu/downloads/alaska-climate-datasets</onlink> </citeinfo> </crossref> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>The input temperature files have been checked to determine that the downscaled output is consistent between CRU and the GCM output. The PET scripts have been proof-read by two people. Results have been reviewed to determine that PET rates are in-line with expectations for the region, but no attempt was made to do a systematic or geographically explicit cross-check against published PET values.</logic> <complete>This dataset covers the state of Alaska.</complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc> 1. Downloaded source data from http://www.snap.uaf.edu. 2. Calculations were performed using R 2.12.1 and 2.12.2 for Mac OS Leopard 3. Data were formatted into geotiffs using the raster and rgdal packages. </procdesc> <procdate>2011</procdate> <proccont> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>The Wilderness Society</cntorg> <cntper>Wendy Loya</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing address</addrtype> <address>705 Christensen Dr.</address> <city>Anchorage</city> <state>Alaska</state> <postal>99501</postal> <country>USA</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>907-272-9453</cntvoice> <cntfax>907-272-1670</cntfax> <cntemail>wendy_loya@tws.org</cntemail> <cntinst>Contact by phone or email.</cntinst> </cntinfo> </proccont> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <direct>Raster</direct> <rastinfo> <rasttype>Grid Cell</rasttype> <rowcount>1320</rowcount> <colcount>2015</colcount> </rastinfo> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <planar> <mapproj> <mapprojn>Albers Conical Equal Area</mapprojn> <albers> <stdparll>55</stdparll> <stdparll>65</stdparll> <longcm>-154</longcm> <latprjo>50</latprjo> <feast>0</feast> <fnorth>0</fnorth> </albers> </mapproj> <planci> <plance>coordinate pair</plance> <coordrep> <absres>0.002048</absres> <ordres>0.002048</ordres> </coordrep> <plandu>meters</plandu> </planci> </planar> <geodetic> <horizdn>North American Datum of 1983</horizdn> <ellips>Geodetic Reference System 80</ellips> <semiaxis>6378137.000000</semiaxis> <denflat>298.257222</denflat> </geodetic> </horizsys> </spref> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>Potential evapotranspiration</enttypl> <enttypd>Estimated values of potential evapotranspiration, in mm.</enttypd> <enttypds>TWS</enttypds> </enttyp> </detailed> <overview> <eaover>These data represent decadal mean totals of potential evapotranspiration estimates (mm).</eaover> <eadetcit> Please see the associated document Hamon_PET_equations.pdf (http://www.snap.uaf.edu/attachments/Hamon_PET_equations.pdf )  for the equations used. Scripts used for the calculation are available upon request to SNAP. Lu, Jianbiao; Sun, Ge; McNulty, Steven G.; Amatya, Devendra (2005). A comparison of six potential evaportranspiration methods for regional use in the southeastern United States. Journal of the American Water Resources Association, 41, 621- 633. </eadetcit> </overview> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</cntorg>
